ABSTRACT
Severe metabolic acidosis can be life-threatening. Its etiology may be obscure, and a
high level of suspicion and appropriate history are keys to recognize and provide
appropriate treatment. This is a puzzling case of recurrent severe acidosis that
illustrates the importance of obtaining medication history to avoid significant harm. A
Hispanic man with DM, HTN, and ESKD on HD presented to the ER with confusion,
dyspnea, and abdominal pain with diarrhea. Labs were significant for CO2<5 mEq/L and
lactic acid of 20.4 mmol/L and venous blood gas pH of 6.7. The patient missed no
dialysis sessions; toxicology screening was negative. He was treated empirically for
sepsis and routine dialysis with resolution of the acidosis. His blood cultures came back
negative, and he was discharged. Two days later, he came back to ER with the same
symptoms, serum CO2<5 mEq/L, and lactic acid 19.5 mmol/L. Workup for DKA, sepsis,
and bowel ischemia was negative. He was treated with dialysis and the acidosis
resolved. He presented again a week later with similar symptoms and serum CO2<5
mEq/L with lactic acid of 17.7 mmol/L. The consulting nephrologist got suspicious and
requested his wife to bring all his medicines from home. It turns out that he was taking
metformin and had forgotten to disclose it. He was dialyzed and improved. He was
instructed to never take metformin again and, in the future, to disclose all medicines
prescribed. Metformin associated metabolic acidosis (MALA) has a high mortality. Since
it is cleared by the kidneys, CKD patients are highly at risk. The drug should not be
taken if eGFR is < 30 ml/min and is contraindicated in dialysis patients. Metformin
toxicity presents as confusion, dyspnea, and GI upset. Treatment is supportive and
dialysis is recommended for encephalopathy, lactic acid > 20 mmol/L or arterial pH<7.
Providers must think broadly as to the cause of severe metabolic derangements. This
case illustrates the importance of a complete patient history and medication
reconciliation to avoid delays in diagnosis that may lead to potential deadly
complications. Peer education to include PCPs, NPs and PAs is of utmost importance to
avoid incidents like this one.
